questions.stem_html: What does Newton’s First Law state?

answers.content_html: The rate of change of momentum of a body is inversely proportional to the external force applied on the body
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that rate of change of momentum of a body is inversely proportional to the external force applied on the body?

answers.content_html: The rate of change of momentum of a body is directly proportional to the external force applied on the body
answers.feedback_html: Isn’t it the second law of motion? Can you recall all the three laws of motion given by Newton?

answers.content_html: A body at rest tends to remain at rest, and a body in motion tends to remain in motion at a constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force
answers.feedback_html: Correct! Newton’s first law states that a body at rest tends to remain at rest, and a body in motion tends to remain in motion at a constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force.

answers.content_html: A body at rest tends to remain at rest, and a body in motion tends to remain in motion at a constant acceleration unless acted upon by a net external force
answers.feedback_html: Do you think accelerated motion is different from the motion where a net external force is acting on the object?

questions.stem_html: According to Newton’s First Law, a body in motion tends to remain in motion at constant velocity. However, when you slide an object across a surface, the object eventually slows down and stops. Why?

answers.content_html: The object experiences a pseudo force of the body in motion, which opposes its motion
answers.feedback_html: Is it correct to say that a pseudo force can bring change in motion of the body?

answers.content_html: The object experiences an internal force exerted by the body itself, which opposes its motion
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that internal forces can oppose the motion of the body? Can you recall Newton’s second law of motion?

answers.content_html: The object experiences the gravitational force exerted by the Earth, which opposes its motion
answers.feedback_html: Do you think the gravitational force which acts perpendicular to the motion of the body will oppose its motion?

answers.content_html: The object experiences a frictional force exerted by the surface, which opposes its motion
answers.feedback_html: Correct! The object experiences a frictional force exerted by the surface, which opposes its motion.

questions.stem_html: How do you express mathematically that no external force is acting on a body?

answers.content_html: F_\text{net} = \infty
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that F_\text{net} = \infty expresses mathematically that no external force is acting on a body?

answers.content_html: F_\text{net} = 1
answers.feedback_html: Is it correct to say that \text{F}_\text{net} = 1 represents no external force is acting on a body? Doesn’t it tell that a unit force is acting in the positive direction?

answers.content_html: F_\text{net} = 0
answers.feedback_html: Correct! F_\text{net} = 0 mathematically means that no external force is acting on a body.

answers.content_html: F_\text{net} = {-1}
answers.feedback_html: Do you think F_\text{net} = {-1} means that no external force is acting on a body? Doesn’t it tell that a unit force is acting in the negative direction?

answers.content_html: Friction is an external force that accelerates motion of the body
answers.feedback_html: Yes, friction is an external force but do you think it accelerates motion of the body? Can you think how a body comes to rest?

answers.content_html: Friction is an external force that decelerates motion of the body
answers.feedback_html: Correct! Friction is an external force that opposes the motion of the body.

answers.content_html: Friction is an internal force that accelerates motion of the body
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that friction is an internal force that accelerates motion of the body? Have you got the definition correctly?

answers.content_html: Friction is an internal force that decelerates motion of the body
answers.feedback_html: It is correct that friction decelerates motion of the body but do you think it is an internal force? Can you differentiate between internal and external forces?

questions.stem_html: Name one thing that the friction between two surfaces may depend on.

answers.content_html: Roughness of the surfaces
answers.feedback_html: Correct! Friction between two surfaces depends on the quality of the surface, that is, on its smoothness or roughness.

answers.content_html: Breadth of the surfaces
answers.feedback_html: Is it correct to say that friction depends on the breadth of the surface? Can you recall definition of friction and the factors on which it is dependent?

answers.content_html: Length of the surfaces
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that friction depends on the dimension of the surfaces? Do you think friction depends on the length of the surface?

answers.content_html: Composition of the surfaces
answers.feedback_html: Do you think friction is a physical quantity which depends on the composition of the surfaces? Can you recall definition of friction?

questions.stem_html: Why does a puck slide more smoothly on an air-hockey table when the air is turned on?

answers.content_html: It increases the gravitational force between the puck and the table
answers.feedback_html: Is it correct to say that air will have any effect on the gravitational force? Also, do you think it will be the right factor to be considered when motion between two surfaces is described?

answers.content_html: It reduces the gravitational force between the puck and the table
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure that air will have any effect on the gravitational force? Also, is it the correct factor to consider when motion between two surfaces is considered?

answers.content_html: It increases the friction between the puck and the table
answers.feedback_html: Do you think if the friction between the puck and the table is increased, the puck will slide more smoothly? Can you recall the definition of friction?

answers.content_html: It reduces the friction between the puck and the table
answers.feedback_html: Correct! The air reduces the friction between the puck and the table
